C70E4AAF780D42BB91DA8F6C940B0F03.description: describe how variations within a population can be an advantage or disadvantage to the survival of a population as environments change.

A5A78D5EB8E64301B34A98B136A43796.description: identify and compare the basic characteristics of organisms, including prokaryotic and eukaryotic, unicellular and multicellular, and autotrophic and heterotrophic; and

7DFD188FEDC84E9CAC9C199039D1C096.description: describe the historical development of cell theory and explain how organisms are composed of one or more cells, which come from pre-existing cells and are the basic unit of structure and function;

E14176F40B7449A5AA5D2591B8EC7808.description: Organisms and environments. The student knows that organisms have an organizational structure and variations can influence survival of populations. The student is expected to:

749F84C77F744DEA9D55E0EF290634F6.description: describe the hierarchical organization of organism, population, and community within an ecosystem.

0043F6A883D54248BAE5694775944151.description: describe and give examples of predatory, competitive, and symbiotic relationships between organisms, including mutualism, parasitism, and commensalism; and

1CEE217E36CB4AC0A362538CB733EC2B.description: investigate how organisms and populations in an ecosystem depend on and may compete for biotic factors such as food and abiotic factors such as availability of light and water, range of temperatures, or soil composition;

697F2EDE4AAD4F209D36E8BF12D69D72.description: Organisms and environments. The student knows that interdependence occurs between living systems and the environment. The student is expected to:

3BF9E1137E7C47678DC587990C908798.description: explain how conservation, increased efficiency, and technology can help manage air, water, soil, and energy resources.

5F8A8BA4937A4E9AA7FA678C5998B294.description: research and describe why resource management is important in reducing global energy, poverty, malnutrition, and air and water pollution, and

121F7E3494434183A9AFFC3FE2BB4658.description: Earth and space. The student understands how resources are managed. The student is expected to:

BDAED808D3CD4E75A025A775270C3D64.description: describe how metamorphic, igneous, and sedimentary rocks form and change through geologic processes in the rock cycle.

88FD44AE680C4F77927ABA2D210808E0.description: model and describe the layers of Earth, including the inner core, outer core, mantle, and crust; and

DE8094CC27214A669ED446FCE83FB066.description: differentiate between the biosphere, hydrosphere, atmosphere, and geosphere and identify components of each system;

1C91B33768A644BAA8596CC78B3D4C19.description: Earth and space. The student understands the rock cycle and the structure of Earth. The student is expected to:

3346C0E4F49E4EB993595C6B126AD27B.description: describe and predict how the positions of the Earth, Sun, and Moon cause daily, spring, and neap cycles of ocean tides due to gravitational forces.

92C63DC7023846FEBC89E302C3DA2101.description: model and illustrate how the tilted Earth revolves around the Sun, causing changes in seasons; and

7C59B25A54614209A5B1948A3F1344F6.description: Earth and space. The student models the cyclical movements of the Sun, Earth, and Moon and describes their effects. The student is expected to:

E025135FB90B4BD0B2A6AF6D47A7EA78.description: explain how energy is transferred through transverse and longitudinal waves.

33310A9D02D54AA3860B338053F1CFDE.description: describe how energy is conserved through transfers and transformations in systems such as electrical circuits, food webs, amusement park rides, or photosynthesis; and

81BCFFAC1B3D481F919395EA64FC55B6.description: compare and contrast gravitational, elastic, and chemical potential energies with kinetic energy;

36004C5EE48F495BAC4D22B6C0323885.description: Force, motion, and energy. The student knows that the total energy in systems is conserved through energy transfers and transformations. The student is expected to:

1504F5A0FEB04DE392C5063C3901ACBB.description: identify simultaneous force pairs that are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction that result from the interactions between objects using Newton's Third Law of Motion.

0299456510B94115BAAE4C04A99F4630.description: calculate the net force on an object in a horizontal or vertical direction using diagrams and determine if the forces are balanced or unbalanced; and

2D52B7D073934540A06A84708ED6F623.description: identify and explain how forces act on objects, including gravity, friction, magnetism, applied forces, and normal forces, using real-world applications;

283291C01EA245C08BC21D8D5D35E879.description: Force, motion, and energy. The student knows the nature of forces and their role in systems that experience stability or change. The student is expected to:

D1846F69FF504E95A15FD0694B078FD1.description: identify the formation of a new substance by using the evidence of a possible chemical change, including production of a gas, change in thermal energy, production of a precipitate, and color change.

0E1C335B3CCB4DDB81811D8506D087AF.description: compare the density of substances relative to various fluids; and

5D043C933D9349BD824D97D7FB203915.description: identify elements on the periodic table as metals, nonmetals, metalloids, and rare Earth elements based on their physical properties and importance to modern life;

D3A270DF78154F37A3F75CB24AF33B6F.description: investigate the physical properties of matter to distinguish between pure substances, homogeneous mixtures (solutions), and heterogeneous mixtures;

EBAB26E36D7C435B85B3E2903BA8B469.description: compare solids, liquids, and gases in terms of their structure, shape, volume, and kinetic energy of atoms and molecules;

34CB8ECD57D54B2CBFB18F89F7E8DEAD.description: Matter and energy. The student knows that matter is made of atoms, can be classified according to its properties, and can undergo changes. The student is expected to:

0D981014055D40CDA326F133FB445C9F.description: analyze and explain how factors or conditions impact stability and change in objects, organisms, and systems.

F83601E28B7D407698E8F8D5A0DF2962.description: analyze and explain the complementary relationship between the structure and function of objects, organisms, and systems; and

71392FDC949547B49D5E22B7D701C50F.description: analyze and explain how energy flows and matter cycles through systems and how energy and matter are conserved through a variety of systems;

BA0738ACB03A4F8DA0FDA89115CE22AA.description: examine and model the parts of a system and their interdependence in the function of the system;

F0F22D4833474A349FAF310975DB5E7A.description: analyze how differences in scale, proportion, or quantity affect a system's structure or performance;

5E1D96C2ED564E2FA56EC4F33ECCBFE8.description: identify and investigate cause-and-effect relationships to explain scientific phenomena or analyze problems;

549EA57480574579A9D06698A499849C.description: Â identify and apply patterns to understand and connect scientific phenomena or to design solutions;

CC9D6E878F714B74BB346B4448D98020.description: Recurring themes and concepts. The student understands that recurring themes and concepts provide a framework for making connections across disciplines. The student is expected to:

CFE16B9F60384103AEF69D577F6EFC9A.description: research and explore resources such as museums, libraries, professional organizations, private companies, online platforms, and mentors employed in a science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) field to investigate STEM careers.

5AE1CCEEF5D146779558A8B94E1F6ACE.description: make informed decisions by evaluating evidence from multiple appropriate sources to assess the credibility, accuracy, cost-effectiveness, and methods used; and

808A5850CDD04562BE51271A622278DB.description: relate the impact of past and current research on scientific thought and society, including the process of science, cost-benefit analysis, and contributions of diverse scientists as related to the content;

C912DAE0E3A243839B812629DF7EF1E7.description: Scientific and engineering practices. The student knows the contributions of scientists and recognizes the importance of scientific research and innovation on society. The student is expected to:

BC062DFA22E94A7F8F21052E9CF83AC5.description: engage respectfully in scientific argumentation using applied scientific explanations and empirical evidence.

2040C81E1D1B420487D233E55BB95969.description: communicate explanations and solutions individually and collaboratively in a variety of settings and formats; and

DC698762D1694206A8C92AFF37857510.description: develop explanations and propose solutions supported by data and models and consistent with scientific ideas, principles, and theories;

971D75839FCD4F7FBA5C68BEDA2A5A8D.description: Scientific and engineering practices. The student develops evidence-based explanations and communicates findings, conclusions, and proposed solutions. The student is expected to:

66B96DE9FEC64CD89404E40F383A6A75.description: use mathematical calculations to assess quantitative relationships in data; and

CB9B1FF9DD8744B68BF36514F11A1EC0.description: analyze data by identifying any significant descriptive statistical features, patterns, sources of error, or limitations;

141E03631F904030869EF89559108E7F.description: identify advantages and limitations of models such as their size, scale, properties, and materials;

57F69A0F5FED474C8B65BA03EEECA660.description: Scientific and engineering practices. The student analyzes and interprets data to derive meaning, identify features and patterns, and discover relationships or correlations to develop evidence-based arguments or evaluate designs. The student is expected to:

CB468B875ABB49729BCA64B55F2F1E7F.description: distinguish between scientific hypotheses, theories, and laws.

37A3845D04CC4DBCBCDEBD387299B046.description: develop and use models to represent phenomena, systems, processes, or solutions to engineering problems; and

0E3C9FE9DC3E4493B79AF76B8944EAA7.description: construct appropriate tables, graphs, maps, and charts using repeated trials and means to organize data;

22D0FEE4A378465EA86D27563424335D.description: collect quantitative data using the International System of Units (SI) and qualitative data as evidence;

CCAB56699C2D4D1A9774D3DC8F4B8D43.description: use appropriate tools such as graduated cylinders, metric rulers, periodic tables, balances, scales, thermometers, temperature probes, laboratory ware, timing devices, pH indicators, hot plates, models, microscopes, slides, life science models, petri dishes, dissecting kits, magnets, spring scales or force sensors, tools that model wave behavior, satellite images, hand lenses, and lab notebooks or journals;

C330F2FC62E64B07A4CC1B6CF3E79C6B.description: use appropriate safety equipment and practices during laboratory, classroom, and field investigations as outlined in Texas Education Agency-approved safety standards;

EB9FCBAA8309435D83B379AEEC57E11E.description: use scientific practices to plan and conduct descriptive, comparative, and experimental investigations and use engineering practices to design solutions to problems;

73181C1A5BD84B3A8BB9435BEC55E217.description: ask questions and define problems based on observations or information from text, phenomena, models, or investigations;

B61F1617F25A4600ADEDD4DFD3CB3DA8.description: Scientific and engineering practices. The student, for at least 40% of instructional time, asks questions, identifies problems, and plans and safely conducts classroom, laboratory, and field investigations to answer questions, explain phenomena, or design solutions using appropriate tools and models. The student is expected to:

85BC1A74DEE94507BACB4CA8B4486508.description: Statements containing the word "including" reference content that must be mastered, while those containing the phrase "such as" are intended as possible illustrative examples.

3A33A1D75EAD4C54A107B245C3E17C1A.description: Recurring themes and concepts. Science consists of recurring themes and making connections between overarching concepts. Recurring themes include structure and function, systems, models, and patterns. All systems have basic properties that can be described in space, time, energy, and matter. Change and constancy occur in systems as patterns and can be observed, measured, and modeled. These patterns help to make predictions that can be scientifically tested. Models have limitations but provide a tool for understanding the ideas presented. Students analyze a system in terms of its components and how these components relate to each other, to the whole, and to the external environment.

F625856A44294F58B8E48DD735CAA2C2.description: Science and social ethics. Scientific decision making is a way of answering questions about the natural world involving its own set of ethical standards about how the process of science should be carried out. Students distinguish between scientific decision-making practices and ethical and social decisions that involve science.

C1C3E4E134A948E3ABC55CA14342801F.description: scientific theories are based on natural and physical phenomena and are capable of being tested by multiple independent researchers. Unlike hypotheses, scientific theories are well established and highly reliable explanations, but they may be subject to change as new areas of science and new technologies are developed.

6EE9C17074264281A37064189A967A1E.description: hypotheses are tentative and testable statements that must be capable of being supported or not supported by observational evidence. Hypotheses of durable explanatory power that have been tested over a wide variety of conditions are incorporated into theories; and

820C28871A2E4496AED91E9D128586D6.description: inferences are conclusions reached on the basis of observations or reasoning supported by relevant evidence;

54796A320A984444A738F6D6A0279CA0.description: observations are active acquisition of either qualitative or quantitative information from a primary source through the senses;

6417E456ECBE44DAB3BA0AC04BE23432.description: Scientific observations, inferences, hypotheses, and theories. Students are expected to know that:

18EE7D4148C74B6DB9F63DF5C2E5CE34.description: Nature of science. Science, as defined by the National Academy of Sciences, is the "use of evidence to construct testable explanations and predictions of natural phenomena, as well as the knowledge generated through this process." This vast body of changing and increasing knowledge is described by physical, mathematical, and conceptual models. Students should know that some questions are outside the realm of science because they deal with phenomena that are not currently scientifically testable.

8EDE6792C1BE44E69A62204DA4923C6C.description: Organisms and environments. All living organisms are made up of smaller units called cells. Ecosystems are organized into communities, populations, and organisms. Students compare and contrast variations within organisms and how they impact survival. Students examine relationships and interactions between organisms, biotic factors, and abiotic factors in an ecosystem.

AA3785EF37214C9EA72870ECB37DB2AD.description: Earth and space. Cycles within Sun, Earth, and Moon systems are studied as students learn about seasons and tides. Students identify that the Earth is divided into spheres and examine the processes within and organization of the geosphere. Researching the advantages and disadvantages of short- and long-term uses of resources enables informed decision making about resource management.

6156FE6B35E44A49B649161F808439E6.description: Force, motion, and energy. Students investigate the relationship between force and motion using a variety of means, including calculations and measurements through the study of Newton's Third Law of Motion. Subsequent grades will study force and motion through Newton's First and Second Laws of Motion. Energy occurs as either potential or kinetic energy. Potential energy can take several forms, including gravitational, elastic, and chemical energy. Energy is conserved throughout systems by changing from one form to another and transfers through waves.

D16CF2D29E614C54A204C9CDD28CDEA4.description: Matter and energy. Students build upon their knowledge of properties of solids, liquids, and gases and further explore their molecular energies. In Grade 6, students learn how elements are classified as metals, nonmetals, or metalloids based on their properties on the Periodic Table. Students have previous experience with mixtures in Grade 5. Grade 6 furthers their understanding by investigating the different types of mixtures. Subsequent grades will learn about compounds. In Grade 6, students compare the density of substances relative to fluids and identify evidence of chemical changes.

C14FE44910D54E5CB9F33EBC96A67A0B.description: Engineering practices. Students identify problems and design solutions using appropriate tools and models.

EB0C981383E44D688821F5967531DDC7.description: Scientific practices. Students ask questions, plan and conduct investigations to answer questions, and explain phenomena using appropriate tools and models.

C6D27041ABB34468987015113201A943.description: Scientific and engineering practices. Scientific inquiry is the planned and deliberate investigation of the natural world using scientific and engineering practices. Scientific methods of investigation are descriptive, correlative, comparative, or experimental. The method chosen should be appropriate to the grade level and question being asked. Student learning for different types of investigations includes descriptive investigations, which have no hypothesis that tentatively answers the research question and involve collecting data and recording observations without making comparisons; correlative and comparative investigations, which have a hypothesis that predicts a relationship and involve collecting data, measuring variables relevant to the hypothesis that are manipulated, and comparing results; and experimental investigations, which involve processes similar to comparative investigations but in which a hypothesis can be tested by comparing a treatment with a control.

6CCFC656BCD3437E93D3D3CF4259102C.description: In Grades 6 through 8 Science, content is organized into recurring strands. The concepts within each grade level build on prior knowledge, prepare students for the next grade level, and establish a foundation for high school courses. In Grade 6, the following concepts will be addressed in each strand.
